PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions bring to its notice and due to have effect from the 21 March, 1985 the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners, and calls upon the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's bill for the abolition of the Assets Test.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the passage of the Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill to repeal the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Kilgariff (from 27 citizens) and Messner (from 220 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving 'property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(iv) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear-Free South Pacific
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we condemn that Australia should assist the United States of America by participating in the testing of MX Peacemaker missiles, or any similar weapons, from Australian shores.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
1. Seek to reverse this deplorable decision and,
2. Ensure that Australia's commitment to a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific be maintained.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Land Value Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That indirect taxes such as sales tax inflate prices, reduce sales, and hence restrict employment opportunities; that land value taxes stimulate the effective use of sites.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will carefully consider the desirability of replacing indirect taxes by a land value tax in order to stimulate Australia's economy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education: Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth that-

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult and any increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) The imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and may deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) Those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. Post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any category of students.
2. Any form of Stamp Duty or similar system of the 'user pays' principle in education not be introduced.
3. Emphasis should be on increasing access to education by, among other things, increasing student financial assistance.
4. The visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
5. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs immediately clarify the government's attitude to the reintroduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, will be absent from the chamber today. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans in relation to his portfolio should be directed to Senator Walsh. Those questions relating to the portfolios which Senator Evans represents in the Senate should be directed to me.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I preface it by saying that I wish I was with Senator Gareth Evans in Perth, the most beautiful city in Australia. We can all take pleasure in the fact that he is today being asked questions about drills in holes and all those other things about which he was anxious to be questioned. I refer the Leader of the Government to the uncertainty and confusion which prevails because of the Attorney-General's apparent inability to make up his mind on the question of indemnities for members of the New South Wales police force who have been asked to give evidence to Mr Justice Stewart. Given that Mr Bowen's indecision has impeded the fight against crime for some months, can the Minister now give the Senate an assurance that indemnities will be granted so that the fight against organised crime can proceed? Further, will the Government agree to make public the advice received from the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Temby, and Mr Justice Stewart on the indemnity question-action which could be taken with very minor editing of the reports? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will direct myself to those aspects of Senator Chaney's comments which I regard as a question and leave aside those parts which I regard as a speech. I concede that this issue, as Senator Chaney implied in his question, has led to some uncertainty. Much of the uncertainty has been generated by an Opposition bereft of ideas and policies which has devoted an enormous amount of attention to this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: The Attorney-General will grant indemnities, if Mr Justice Stewart so advises and recommends, where he is satisfied that a person can give evidence which will lead to the prosecution of a criminal offence. I said that the issue was complex, and the Opposition has sought to derive some comfort from its complexity. Tomorrow the Attorney-General will meet Mr Temby and Mr Justice Stewart to discuss the implementation of these matters. I again refer to the complexity because, for example, there are now, of quite recent discovery, two sets of Age tapes. Indemnities have been sought in respect of the Age tapes which were taken apparently between 1976 and 1981. It is known now that the so-called Age tapes extend to 1984 and that has to be considered with Mr Justice Stewart and Mr Temby.

The question Senator Chaney raised, on the possibility of publication, in a general sense, of the Temby report and the Stewart report on the indemnity issue, is a matter for discussion and, if possible, agreement between the Attorney-General and the two law officers concerned. Those discussions, as I have indicated, will take place tomorrow. Mr Justice Stewart has, as I understand it, to this stage been firmly against the publication of his report. I am not sure-I can obtain instructions on this-what precise position Mr Temby has taken in relation to the publication of his report.

I heard Senator Chaney on the AM program this morning who, from the tranquil fields of Opposition, made a judgment about this matter. He was satisfied he said-Lord Justice Chaney is satisfied-that the reports ought to be published.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am being offered a job.

—There was another character in the same opera called Pooh Bah and that name might apply equally to Senator Chaney. Senator Chaney has rushed to judgment, for political purposes, on this matter. From the point of view of the Government, it is at least courteous to have a discussion with the two gentlemen concerned and reach some agreement about the publication and, indeed, the manner in which publication should be made. As I said, those discussions will take place tomorrow.

—I have a supplementary question. Among the many which could follow that answer, I ask the Minister: Is he saying that indemnity will be granted where that could lead to a prosecution? Does that mean 'may lead to a prosecution', or is Mr Justice Stewart required, in effect, to certify to the Government that prosecution will follow? What is the level of certainty required at this stage prior to the actual evidence having been obtained by Mr Justice Stewart?

—It is my understanding that any police officer who gives evidence to a royal commission at present is not liable to prosecution in respect of matters arising from that evidence. I think that is probably common ground among the amateur lawyers, such as myself, who are in this Parliament. That being so, I think the question asked by Senator Chaney has a somewhat different character about it. What he is, in effect, asking me is whether Mr Justice Stewart has to certify that the giving of a particular piece of evidence will lead to a prosecution. I would have thought that would be an immensely difficult thing for him to do, as a matter of opinion. The Government will act, given those general parameters, on the advice of Mr Justice Stewart. I would prefer not to attempt to answer the question further until the discussions to which I have referred have taken place tomorrow because there are a number of nuances and so on in this matter which I think have to be thrashed out between Mr Justice Stewart, the Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney-General.
—Can the Minister for Community Services inform the Senate whether the Queensland Government applies a means test to home care and aids for the disabled programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer, very briefly-but which will require some explanation, you will be surprised to hear, Mr President-is yes, the Queensland Government does apply means tests to its own schemes to provide aids for disabled people and for their home help and home care schemes, which it funds partly from Commonwealth funds through the States Grants (Home Care) Act. The interesting thing about these means tests, in the light of complaints about the assets test from Queensland National Party senators and from Queensland Government members and Ministers during the last election campaign, is that these tests are, indeed, means tests. The Queensland Government assesses people as to their income and their assets, and the upper limit of asset holdings in Queensland before one loses the free home care help assistance is a total of $5,000. So if people, in fact, have more than $5,000 worth of assets they have to start paying for the home help services and the home nursing services, which of course are partly funded by the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation with aids for disabled is even more interesting. There are two schemes of this type in Queensland. The Queensland Government, like other State governments, administers Commonwealth funds under the aids for disabled program-the PAD scheme-and in administering those funds it applies no means test. It also has its own State scheme for the supply of aids for the disabled and in those it supplies not only an income test but also an assets test. The upper level of the assets test is, again, $5,000. I think this demonstrates the absolute hypocrisy of people such as the Queensland National Party senators who come in here and say that we should pay full pensions and full fringe benefits to people with assets in excess of $500,000, but their own State Government, in applying assets tests and means tests to home help, et cetera, put an upper limit of $5,000 on their own benighted citizens. The hypocrisy is typical of the Queensland representatives on the other side of this place and absolutely typical of the Queensland Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to Premier Wran's disclosure of the possibility that the New South Wales police tapes extend back to 1967. If, as now seems to be indicated, the Government after months of indecision may at last agree to indemnify the New South Wales police involved, will he give the Senate an unequivocal assurance that Mr Justice Stewart's terms of reference regarding the tapes and the powers available to him are sufficient to investigate all aspects of the tapes and effectively to explore all aspects of organised crime that they disclose, including crimes which fall outside terms of reference of the National Crime Authority?

—The answer to that question is no, of course I will not give the Senate an unequivocal assurance on that matter. Senator Teague floats into Question Time in this chamber with a bit of ad libbing from the Premier of New South Wales, as I understand it-it is not much more than that-that the tapes go back to 1967. I do not know of any formal statement that has been made to that effect. However, if that is so, it is a matter which the government would want to consider. It is probably a matter which the Opposition's former government would have wanted to consider in a great deal of detail.
—That even covers your former government and the former Attorney-General.
—That is absolutely right. I certainly do not give any unequivocal assurances about that, but it becomes a sensible and necessary step. The Government will consider it and consider it favourably.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FLINDERS UNIVERSITY, SOUTH AUSTRALIA: CHAIR OF MODERN GREEK

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Education to the long-standing proposal to introduce modern Greek at Flinders University in South Australia. I ask: Is it a fact that Federal funding was both promised and allocated for this project and that the South Australian Government and the local Greek community are prepared to contribute to the establishment of a chair of modern Greek? Is it also a fact that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission recommended funding for this project in its report of September 1984? Will the Minister now indicate why there is a delay in the inception of this much needed course?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the Commonwealth has expressed support for the establishment of a chair of modern Greek at Flinders University and will, in due course, make funds available for that purpose. The project, in its early stages, is to be funded jointly by the Greek community and the State Government and later by Commonwealth support. I think they were the terms in which the election undertaking that initiated this project was made. The Commonwealth Government's commitment was made against the background of the significant community and State Government support which is now forthcoming. The Tertiary Education Commission addressed this matter in its Volume 2 advice but did not recommend Commonwealth funding for 1985. Pages 19 and 20 of that report state:

ANSWER.PARA: On the basis that the community and State Government financial support were forthcoming, no Commonwealth funds will be required in 1985. The University's Council has not provided the $100,000 for 1986 and the $150,000 for 1987 within the University's grants for those years as it considered the Government's broader intake objectives should have priority.

However, both the South Australian Government and the Greek community have now given undertakings to provide financial support in 1985 for the initial establishment of the chair. As I said, Commonwealth funds will not be available for 1985. The question of the level of Commonwealth support required for 1986 and beyond to maintain the chair will be addressed by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in its supplementary report for the triennium, which I expect to receive shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. In answering a question from Senator Chaney earlier in Question Time, the Minister indicated that the granting of indemnity to the police officers mentioned in Mr Justice Stewart's eighth interim report would be determined according to recommendations from Mr Justice Stewart. Is the Minister saying that it is likely that not all the 31 police officers mentioned will be or could be given indemnity? If that is the case, that is, if Mr Justice Stewart does not recommend indemnity for all 31 police officers, does this mean that those police officers not granted indemnity will be or could be prosecuted? Can the Minister say whether the New South Wales Premier, Mr Wran, will also be granting indemnity only to some of the policemen? If so, will it be to the same police officers, that is, will the New South Wales and Federal governments reach some agreement regarding which police officers will be granted indemnity and which will not?

—As distinct from Senator Chipp, who has been locked in earnest conversation with Senator Haines in the last few minutes, I do not have the advantage of having read Mr Justice Stewart's report. However, let me say that there are two situations. As I understand it-certainly there is a rumour about-Mr Justice Stewart has embraced the view that a blanket indemnity should be granted for the 31 officers concerned. It is perfectly true to say, as Senator Haines puts it in her question, that if Mr Justice Stewart does not recommend the granting of an indemnity in respect of the circumstances which I dealt with in my answer to Senator Chaney, particular officers will not be granted an indemnity because there will not be a recommendation from the judge to that effect. As I said in my answer to Senator Chaney, the fact that indemnity is not granted does not necessarily render any officers not granted an indemnity liable to prosecution if they are giving evidence to a royal commission. It does not render them liable to prosecution at all. I make the comment that the 31 policemen have a fairly high ambit claim on this issue. Insofar as I am asked about what the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, might do, I am not in a position to answer that part of the question. Certainly I cannot say what the New South Wales Government might do about indemnities at this stage. Of course, we can try to find that out for the honourable senator but I do not know what that Government's position is. If I can obtain further information I will make it available to Senator Haines in due course.
—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister then believe that it would be advisable for the New South Wales and Federal governments to grant indemnities to the same police officers?

—My belief about that matter is totally irrelevant. It has to be determined on the facts in each case and, as I have said in answers to previous questions here, the Government will act on the recommendation of Mr Justice Stewart. It is the recommendation of Mr Justice Stewart which is the relevant fact, not the belief of the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health whether he has seen reports in the Advocate indicating that he has said that the Federal Government would be prepared to give approval in principle to the establishment of a private hospital in Burnie. Can the Minister say whether he has been quoted accurately by Mr Talbot of Australian Hospital Care Pty Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention was drawn to an article in the north-west Advocate in Tasmania which said that I had given the representatives of Australian Hospital Care Pty Ltd to believe that the Federal Government would approve in principle a private hospital on the north-west coast. There are no private hospital facilities on the north-west coast of Tasmania and at the moment there are at least two competing organisations which wish to set up a private hospital-one in Burnie and one, I understand, in Devonport. The State Government, wishing of course to divest itself of public facilities, would prefer that such a private hospital be in Ulverstone by its selling the Ulverstone hospital to private interests. When I was Acting Minister for Health I saw representatives of Australian Hospital Care Pty Ltd and told then two things. First I said that the Federal Government would consider giving approval in principle to the establishment of a private hospital on the north-west coast of Tasmania. I said that I did not favour any particular site and I did not suggest that we would favour any particular site. I also told them that such recommendations would be considered when the State Government made recommendations to the Federal Government on where that hospital should be and by whom it should be operated.

ANSWER.PARA: I can understand the difficulties and the frustrations of the various groups involved which want to set up a private hospital, but those difficulties and frustrations are not the fault of the Federal Government. The difficulty is that the State Government-and particularly Mr Cleary, the State Minister for Health, who has great difficulty in making up his mind about anything and, when he does, has to go back to the Premier and seek the Premier's permission before he can give a view on anything-will not make a decision. The great difficulty which governments of that type have in Tasmania is that they cannot make up their minds whether they should please the voters of Burnie, the voters of Ulverstone, the voters of Devonport or none at all. When the State Government makes a recommendation, the Federal Government will consider it. But until that happens, I am afraid that Australian Hospital Care Pty Ltd, and other such organisations, will have to remain frustrated.

In this competitive situation, I can understand that the organisation may have misstated what I said, but I am in no doubt about what I said at all. I made those statements to that organisation after having been fully briefed on the situation by the Department of which I was Acting Minister at the time. The ball is at the feet of the Tasmanian Government, not the Federal Government, at present. I hope that the Tasmanian Government will eventually make up its mind as to just what it wants to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to the answer that he gave to me last week, in which he denied being committed to any particular mix of taxes, including a capital gains tax, as part of a package involved with a move to greater emphasis on indirect taxation. Does the Minister agree that he was rather more definite in a speech that he made to the Commonwealth and State women's advisers in Canberra on Friday last, when he said that it would be difficult to see how desired changes to the tax system could be achieved 'without some form of capital gains tax'? Will the Minister now explain what he sees as the virtues of a capital gains tax and indicate, without committing himself of course, whether he has now a personal preference for this means of obtaining extra revenue in the same way as has the Leader of the Government in the Senate expressed his personal preference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Half of this Senate-people such as Senator Peter Rae, the Liberals, the National Party, the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine-continues to pursue a policy which allows people who plunder the public purse to keep the money that they have already pinched after they have been found out, but says: 'We will take it off them if they keep pinching money from the public purse', as distinct from the policy of the present Government, which says: 'If you are found out pinching money from the public purse you will have to pay it back; you have got to pay back what you have pinched, as well as that which you may pinch the next day'. In other words, Senator Peter Rae and his ilk refuse to pass effective legislation which will take back from tax evaders the money that they stole yesterday as well as that which they may have anticipated stealing tomorrow. As long as they continue to pursue such a policy it is difficult to see how blatant tax avoidance schemes of the type endorsed by just over half this Senate last week can be closed off in any way other than by putting in place a mechanism which ensures that receipts or cash flows which are, in fact, income, but which are disguised as something else, are taxed as income.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Peter Rae correctly quoted my answer of last week. I said that I do not see how it is possible to close off tax avoidance without some measure which changes the definition of capital gain, as it has been laid down by the courts and is accepted, and converts it to income. If Senator Peter Rae can suggest some way of dealing with that problem and thereby closing off the conversion of income into capital for the clear, explicit purpose of avoiding taxation, I should be very pleased to hear it. But at this stage, I cannot think of any other way of doing it. I can only assume from the implicit criticism-explicit criticism often comes from the Liberal Party and other Opposition parties on this question-that their favouritism towards tax evaders and tax avoiders is more general than that which they normally express; that is, not only will they refuse to issue a credible threat of retrospectivity to close off tax avoidance, but also they will stop any other means of closing off tax avoidance.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of supplementary question, will the Minister, instead of abusing his colleagues in another place who have engaged in tax avoidance and calling them plunderers of the public purse, answer the question I asked him, which was: Will the Minister, without committing himself necessarily, state whether he has a personal preference for a capital gains tax as a means of obtaining extra revenue? Does he or does he not have such a personal preference?
—I have a very strong personal preference for putting a steel trap under tax avoidance and tax evasion. I just wish that members of the Opposition shared that preference.

—I address my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has he seen the article in today's Canberra Times headed 'Doubts over financial advice to pensioners', which is based partly on his response yesterday to Senator Black's question regarding avoidance of the pension income test? Do the reported comments by various bank managers to the effect that it is not their responsibility to advise pensioners one way or the other on the wisdom of investing large sums of money in non-interest-bearing accounts partly explain the prevalence of such accounts under the previous income test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the article in today's Canberra Times in which both Senator Grimes and I have been quoted, following Question Time yesterday. I am somewhat appalled by the laissez-faire attitude with which the particular bank managers regard their responsibilities and obligations to the customers' welfare and interests. I was particularly interested in the comments attributed to the Australian Capital Territory Manager of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited who is reported as saying that it is the customers' prerogative to deposit funds in non-interest-bearing accounts in order to qualify for the pension or fringe benefits. He went to some lengths to say that that was a proper course of action. He also said that in the circumstances the bank accepted the money and the customer was not advised one way or the other, to use his words. I find this statement rather odd in view of the claim made by the bank's brochure promoting its retirement service, a copy of which I have here, under the heading 'Advice you can trust'. It goes on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . a great help when it comes to organising things like a regular income, security for your future, your pension eligibility and tax aspects of your investment programme.
The brochure, under the heading 'The Pension. Your eligibility' also says:
Your eligibility, or more importantly, your potential to realise your full eligibility is crucial to you. Our advisers are constantly updating on the relevant entitlements and qualifications.

I also find it somewhat ironical that the service pensioner to whom I referred in replying to the question that I was asked yesterday with assessable assets of $356,000, including $354,000 in a non-interest bearing account, had his money in the ANZ Bank. Just this morning another case involving a service pensioner, a customer of the ANZ Bank in Queensland, was brought to my attention. This single home-owning pensioner had $135,000 in the bank, $100,000 of which was earning no interest at all. I have calculated that, after allowing for his pension entitlement, fringe benefits, tax and income test threshold and so on, he was being deprived of at least $3,000 a year by poor advice or, more likely, no advice whatsoever. Honourable senators will, of course, be familiar with this sort of advice from people in banking institutions, in particular from the ANZ Bank, which claims in its retirement services brochure to be 'the bank that serves you best'. It ought to change its slogan and call itself 'the bank that serves itself best' in view of the advice it is giving pensioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance publicly canvassed the possibility of a considerable tightening of the taxation of employee fringe benefits? What return to Commonwealth revenue would he expect to result from greater scrutiny of benefits such as discounted air fares, subsidised canteen services, entertainment expenses, free beer for brewery employees at their work breaks and free weekend meat for butchers' apprentices, which is common? If the Minister believes such benefits should be taxed, does he foresee any practical difficulties in light of comments such as those of the New South Wales Secretary of the Transport Workers Union, Mr Harry Quinn, who, in reacting to suggestions that members employed by Qantas Australia Ltd might be hit by the taxing of discounted air fares, said: 'There'd be the biggest industrial upheaval in years'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked whether I had publicly canvassed the taxation of fringe benefits. I do not claim that my memory is infallible, but I do not remember having done so. The second part of the question was about what revenue it is estimated would be obtained if all fringe benefits were taxed. I think there are some rough Australian Taxation Office estimates around. I will try to obtain them from the Treasurer. The definition of what is a fringe benefit is, at least at the margin, somewhat arbitrary. For example, I discovered recently that there is a $1.3m loss on the operations of the dining room in this Parliament once all wage costs are taken into account. That averages out at something like $5,000 for each member of Parliament. That then raises the question of whether we each should have added on to our taxable incomes $5,000 to cover the notional loss to the dining room. I do not know whether Senator Short is suggesting that that should be done. If he is, I am certainly willing to consider it and to propose to the Treasurer either that it be taxed as imputed income or that dining room charges be increased so that the loss is reduced.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to other fringe benefits, it has been suggested by some people that former Treasury officials who leaked documents obtained the fringe benefit of Liberal Party preselection for seats in 1975, but I do not know how we could quantify or tax that benefit. The concept of a fringe benefit being that of having access to Treasury documents which can be leaked, with the reward of Liberal Party endorsement for a seat, is one that is hard to grasp.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Community Services seen the reported complaints from the Tasmanian Minister for Community Welfare, Mr Cleary, about the Commonwealth's failure to approve funding for a child care centre at Lower Gagebrook? Is there any basis for Mr Cleary's complaint? What are the facts about the delay for this centre? When will construction begin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen those reports. Mr Cleary has been very active in that regard this week. Mr Cleary is the Minister responsible for children's services, among other things, in Tasmania. As I said in answer to a previous question, he is a very difficult person to negotiate with for two reasons: First, he has trouble making up his mind; secondly, when one does come to a position with Mr Cleary, that is not the end of it because he has to go back to the State Premier, Mr Gray, and find out whether what he has done is okay, and if it is not okay he comes back again, and the negotiations tend to be endless. But he is always very quick to criticise the Federal Government, particularly when the Federal Government is not at fault.

ANSWER.PARA: There is in fact an occasional care centre at Gagebrook, as there is at nearby Bridgewater, which is funded by the Federal Government through both salary subsidies and fee relief. The Gagebrook people have put in an application for the funding of a child care centre. Under the Commonwealth-State arrangements, that application is considered by a Commonwealth-State committee. That Commonwealth-State committee is still considering the matter of funding for the Gagebrook child care centre. Mr Cleary knows that all funds for Tasmania for this budgetary year have been expended. He also knows that the committee is considering this matter and that the first opportunity to fund the Gagebrook centre would be after the next Budget. Despite that, Mr Cleary has the cheek to get up in the Tasmanian Parliament and say that the fault is with the Federal Government because it will not consider the centre and will not fund it.

Mr Cleary knows that this is a matter of co-operation between the State and Federal governments. We have had agreements with the States to assist us in the planning and funding of child care centres. Most States are willing to provide some financial assistance, some land and, in some cases, buildings to increase the number of child care centres that are available. In the last two years of office of this Government we have increased the number by 70 per cent. Sometimes Tasmania provides land and sometimes it provides buildings. In Gagebrook the Tasmanian Government is willing to provide the land. But the Tasmanian Government is unwilling in this area as in others to provide any finance; all we get is carping criticism from the inadequate Minister in Tasmania. I dare say this will go on week after week and occasionally I will have to answer it. However, the simple fact of the matter is that this matter is before a Commonwealth-State committee which is considering it. Mr Cleary, I believe, does know it is before that committee. If he does not know, he is incompetent. However, as I believe he does know, his statement to the Tasmanian Parliament was deliberately misleading. In fact, it was a deliberate lie, and I hope that the people of Gagebrook know that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 418. The Minister said that a certain statement was deliberately misleading. I believe that he has contravened the Standing Orders and I ask that he withdraw.

—I withdraw the statement that he is deliberately misleading the Tasmanian Parliament. The obvious implication, if he is not deliberately misleading the people, is that he is incompetent.

—Are you going to withdraw the assets test?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. As unleaded petrol is to be introduced in Australia this year, and the technology required to produce engines which can run on unleaded petrol has never been used in this country, will this mean that the high technology engines and high technology fuel delivery systems will need to be imported? Will this bring about a virtual dominance of Japanese engine design in local vehicles? Will this threaten the plans that have been made for the restructuring of the motor industry and how will this, in turn, affect job prospects in the vehicle industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Local engine manufacturers will need to undertake only minor design modifications in order to make their engines suitable for use with unleaded petrol. A number of companies have already established plants or facilities in order to provide that conversion process. It is not anticipated that there will be any significant increase in imports of engines because of the introduction of unleaded petrol. In the Government's view, the introduction of unleaded petrol will not bring about a virtual dominance of Japanese engine design in Australian vehicles, but let me say that that is a risk that this industry in Australia has always run, irrespective of leaded or unleaded petrol. That is a matter to which the motor car plan is, in part, addressed. It is trying to get some resolution of the difficult problem of local sourcing of engines and the joint ventures, in a sense, to produce local engines.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the question related to whether the introduction of unleaded petrol threatens the Government's passenger motor vehicle plan in any way. In part I have answered that. The question also related to employment in this industry. The plan is devoted to long term stability in the motor vehicle industry and the capacity of that industry to expand and provide secure employment. As I have said in the Senate on numerous occasions since the plan was announced, inevitably there will be reductions of employment in the motor vehicle industry. That is happening throughout the world and there is no reason why Australia should be immune from that process, unless we wish to continue with production measures which were relevant 10, 15 or 20 years ago but which are not relevant to the production of contemporary motor cars using contemporary technology. That process will happen. I have said from the beginning that employment in 1992 at the end of the period of the motor vehicle plan will, in my view and in the view of all the car manufacturers, be less than it is now. However, it will not be affected by the introduction of unleaded petrol. Having said that, I appreciate Senator Foreman's concern about the changes which affect the motor vehicle industry and the possible impact which they may have on the operation of the motor vehicle plan. Senator Foreman has been continually alert and questioning about these issues, coming as he does from South Australia which has a very important component of its industry tied up with the production of motor vehicles.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QUEENSLAND: SECESSION FROM THE COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has his attention been drawn to a statement in yesterday's Courier-Mail in which the Premier of Queensland hinted at further strike Bills in Queensland and to a number of statements in which the Premier said that Mr Hawke was reluctant to criticise the new Queensland anti-union legislation because he was jealous of it? Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen went on to say that Queensland would secede from the Commonwealth of Australia if it did not get a fair deal at the coming Premiers Conference. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: If they don't want to treat us according to the Constitution, then we will jump into it alone.

He confirmed that this meant taking steps to gain independence from the rest of Australia. What is the Federal Government's attitude to the statements made by the Premier and can the Minister inform the Senate as to what legal right the Premier has in relation to Queensland's secession from the Commonwealth of Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement allegedly made by the Premier of Queensland has been drawn to my attention.
—That is funny.

—Yes, it is funny. I understand that yesterday Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen confirmed that he meant that steps would be taken to gain independence for Queensland from the rest of Australia. I believe that there will be further consideration of this matter by the Premier of Queensland. In 1934 Western Australia petitioned the Parliament of Westminster seeking preliminary steps to be taken in respect of the secession of that State from the Commonwealth of Australia. That petition was not greeted with warmth by the United Kingdom and in fact was rejected. I remind honourable senators that the preamble to the Constitution Act of the United Kingdom Parliament, by which the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act was established, recites the agreement of the people of the several colonies of Australia 'to unite in one indissoluble Federal Commonwealth under the Crown'. Most of us, except one or two of Irish extraction, would be grateful for that recitation which appears in the preamble to the Constitution Act. Neither the Constitution nor the Constitution Act makes any provision for secession of a State. Section 128 of the Constitution sets out the only practical method of amendment to the Constitution, and that is by referendum. The application of section 128 of the Constitution to the covering provision-namely, the one to which I have referred, the Constitution Act-is a matter on which there are differing views amongst distinguished lawyers. Having drawn attention to the legal difficulties involved, I remind the Senate of the practical consequences which could possibly occur. For example, members of this Government would be buoyed up by the absence of withering attacks on the capacity of our Government from Senator Sheil, Senator Boswell and Senator MacGibbon. On the other hand, I would personally miss Senator Bjelke-Petersen in this chamber. There would be even graver consequences than that, because if the proposal for Queensland to secede from the Commonwealth of Australia were put to a referendum, I remind the Premier that there is a distinct possibility that most Queenslanders would not vote for it, but most people in the rest of the Commonwealth would.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to comments reported in today's Press about the Commonwealth Government's planned introduction of a cash bonus bidding system for oil exploration permits? Can the Minister provide the Senate with the background to this decision by the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Press comments. I also have a copy of most of the rather extraordinary speech delivered yesterday by the Premier of Western Australia. Mr Burke displayed a degree of conceptual ignorance of the subject which was matched only by his political impertinence. I say political impertinence because the policy in question is the auctioning of or the seeking of cash bids for oil exploration permits in off-shore areas, which the High Court of Australia decreed in 1975 are Commonwealth territories, apart from it being a Commonwealth policy. So much for the political impertinence. As for the conceptual ignorance, among other things he said:

ANSWER.PARA: We are strongly opposed to the concept--
that is of cash bids--
simply because it would increase the cost of exploration.

How a cash bid increases the cost of drilling a well must remain a matter for wide eyed conjecture. Senator Gareth Evans is to speak at the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association conference in Perth today. I suppose reading this might be sort of breaking the embargo on a small part of his speech, but he will comment on the assertion that cash bidding will reduce the funds available for exploration. He is going to say:

The assumption underlying this argument is that the funds available for exploration are fixed, that the Australian exploration industry is a closed shop within which a given amount of funds circulate without either escaping or being topped up.
That of course does not describe the actual situation. The Western Australian Premier also said, speaking of cash bidding:
It discourages exploration companies from sinking sufficient wildcat wells . . .

A wildcat well, by definition, is a well sunk in completely unknown and uncharted territory. In such territory, one would expect the cash bids to be zero and, therefore, the whole issue to disappear off the agenda. I can only presume that Mr Burke does not understand the principle involved in an auction system-if he did he would not have made the comments he did-or, alternatively, that he has fallen victim to propaganda from industry interests who, of course, would rather obtain exploration permit areas for nothing than have to compete with some other company to obtain the right to exploit minerals which may be present. There is, however, one gratifying comment in Mr Burke's speech. Given especially that this Government bent over backwards two or three weeks ago to rescue the Western Australian Government from the consequences of the take or pay gas contract which the previous Liberal State Government had bequeathed it, Mr Burke also said:
We do not believe that the cash bonus bid system is an acceptable means of raising government revenue.

I anticipate that there will be no claims from the Western Australian Government for any revenue so raised. There are, of course, other very practical advantages in the cash bonus bidding system in terms of providing a more objective means of allocating perceived prospective areas to competing companies. I suggest that those honourable senators who want to know more of the technical details of that read Senator Gareth Evans's speech which is to be delivered in Perth today.

—Whatever you were reading.
